description: From fidge (“to fidget”) +‎ *-et (frequentative ending), possibly from Middle English *-ten, from Old English -ettan.

entries.meaning: A nervous wriggling or twitching motion.
(informal) A person who fidgets, especially habitually.
A toy intended to be fidgeted with.

verbs.description: fidget (third-person singular simple present fidgets, present participle fidgeting or fidgetting, simple past and past participle fidgeted or fidgetted)

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To wiggle or twitch; to move the body, especially the fingers, around nervously or idly.
(transitive) To cause to fidget; to make uneasy.
